title: 111_hr5913
content: The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for various expenses related to the program, with the federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the total cost. Promotion of the program through various marketing methods. Federal share of grant not to exceed 75% of program cost. Grant amounts to supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for program activities. SEC. 3. PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with certain requirements: the agency must administer the program, incoming text messages must be stripped of identifying information, texts must be untraceable, the program cannot replace existing hotlines, personnel must be trained to respond to text tips, the program should be compatible with most mobile phone providers, and include unidentifiable features. The law enforcement agency's texting program should be compatible with most mobile phone providers and include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to send follow-up information. It should also have a feature to abort tips and not impose additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones. The agency should promote the texting program to encourage citizens to participate. The law enforcement agency should promote the texting program to encourage citizens, especially youth, to participate. Standard messaging rates from the tipster's mobile phone provider will apply, and no additional fees will be imposed. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must also include certifications that the program meets the Act's requirements. Additionally, reports and evaluations are required under this Act. Under SEC. 5 of the Act, recipients of grants must submit yearly reports to the Attorney General on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant. The Attorney General, in turn, must submit a yearly report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the effectiveness of activities under the Act. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines a "texting tip program" as a program allowing citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice. It also authorizes $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016 for the Attorney General to carry out this Act.
